review_title: A Dynamic Organization with High Expectations
pros:
Making Waves is an organization constantly evolving to meet the needs of those it serves, and to respond to changing educational and non-profit sector landscapes. I worked under the supervision of Melissa Fries for eight years in various capacities. Melissa Fries was an exceptional leader and mentor who took on tough challenges by remaining consistent and focused, and keeping very high standards for herself and her staff. I had many opportunities for project management and professional development. If I had an idea, I had to justify it, plan it, and assure it was executed responsibly. Some of my best professional development experiences came via colleagues who were entrusted with sharing their expertise with the rest of us. 

As I  advance my career, I look back at Making Waves as a place where I was allowed to do my best work and I was recognized and appreciated for it. That Making Waves continues to expand its services speaks to the collective efforts all of the families and staff that have been a part of it.
cons: Making Waves is a very much driven by a vision and mission. This means not everyone will agree at all times about how those are achieved, and what approaches are more suitable. While I was there, the organization had a (necessary) tension between developing programmatic structure and bureaucracy, particularly to ensure sustainability, and nurturing autonomy in order to let the best ideas flow. This means anyone who works there needs to be comfortable in this environment.

pros:
I worked at Making Waves for over a decade under the direction of Melissa Fries, our Director.  Throughout the years, as the education landscape shifted, and its funding model came under threat, our organization transitioned from serving primary, secondary and post-secondary students to working exclusively with high school graduates helping them get through college and beyond.  

During the transition, we were not always sure that our doors would remain open.  I watched Melissa plan and work tirelessly to maintain not only quality programming for our students, but also ensure that our workforce could move forward so that staff could remain employed.  It was her vision that led to the development of a robust College and Alumni Program that allowed for continuing to serve the Wave-Makers who had already been in the program for years, as well as be able to recruit and assist new students to help them persist through college.  I am sure that were it not for her efforts, the program would not still exist, in any form—which would be a shame considering all the students, families and staff who were helped over the years, and continue to be so.  

We were a small start-up in the beginning, which meant everyone performed multiple jobs, including the boss.  Melissa spent much time performing many of the job duties—inclusive of working directly with students—for which she would later hire staff as we grew.  This gave her direct insight and perspective into the challenges and needs of staff that made her an effective advocate for her employees within the larger organization.  She constantly researched and familiarized herself with changing trends in the field that fueled her decision-making and allowed our organization to remain relevant and sustainable in its practices.  

My career development and professional growth were encouraged under her direction.  I would describe her leadership style as confident and tough, but fair.  She had high expectations regarding quality of work, which was critical considering the under-resourced students we served.  She was always very open to suggestions to address our evolving needs as we grew, and advocated constantly for not only our students, but the employees’ needs as well.  Staff were encouraged to generate ideas that would allow our work to improve.  If we saw a more efficient way to approach a task or arrive at a needed outcome, we could submit a proposal to demonstrate the viability of the idea, and actually be allowed to implement the procedural change moving forward, for which we received the credit within the organization.  Hard work was always rewarded, and there was room for progression in responsibilities, professional growth, and job and salary advancement.  

When I reflect on my career trajectory since then, I have developed a sincere appreciation for my time working at Making Waves.  Working under the direction of Melissa Fries allowed me to grow and create opportunities for myself that I may not have otherwise developed.
cons: The cons were typical of many workplaces, and nothing unique to Making Waves.  (Everybody has a boss to whom they must answer, including the boss.)
